title: Thursday, 24th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:06 am
PM11:07am

Hi there

PM11:07am

We had a tech snafu

PM11:07am

But that's now been sorted, hopefully

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Let's move straight to a pic for today

PM11:08am

PM11:08am

Robert Chote

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Chairs the Office for Budget responsibility

PM11:08am

And he's the latest one to get it in the neck from certain sections of the press

PM11:09am

For "getting it wrong"

11:09 am
PM11:09am

yes, the mail http://www.dailyma...conomy-gloomy.html

PM11:09am

Oh, and Jeremy Warner, who points out he used to be Chote's boss

PM11:09am

Back in the days of the Independent

11:09 am
PM11:09am

http://www.telegra...-just-ask-the-off/

PM11:10am

Of course Chote also ex the FT

undefined
11:10 am
PM11:10am

Suppose we should do a brief bit of strategy reaction to the Autumn statement

BE11:11am

Sure.

PM11:11am

How about John Wraith of UBS?

11:11 am
PM11:11am

GDP expected to slow to 1.4% in 2017, 1.7% in 2018
The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) has materially lowered its forecast for
growth in the UK, anticipating an increase in GDP of 1.4% next year, and 1.7% in
2018. These compare with 2.2% and 2.1% respectively at the time of the Budget in
March. GDP is expected to reaccelerate thereafter to 2.1%, the same rate as in the
previous forecast, which we view as an optimistic expectation given the likelihood of
prolonged economic uncertainty as a result of the UK's forthcoming exit from the EU.
CPI forecast to accelerate to 2.3% in 2017, 2.5% in 2018 due to sterling decline
The OBR shares the consensus view that while growth is set to decelerate over the
coming period, inflation is likely to rise as the significant devaluation of sterling over the
past year – with the trade weighted fall since November 2015 of -17.5% similar to that
seen during the first year of the Global Financial Crisis in 2007/08 – transmits from
rising import prices to the consumer. We think CPI will rise faster over the coming year.

PM11:11am

Borrowing rises by £12.7bn in this fiscal year, seen £20.2bn higher in 2017
The weaker growth outlook has led to an upward revision in borrowing projections,
primarily as a consequence of the decision to allow the automatic stabilisers to fully
deploy. The budget deficit is expected to be £68.2bn in 2016, £59.0bn in 2017, and
£46.5bn in 2018. These forecasts are very close to our own (£70bn, £60bn, £45bn
respectively). The Debt Management Office (DMO) confirmed that the higher funding
requirement in the current fiscal year will be met by increasing Gilt issuance by
£15.0bn, also in line with our forecast. Short and long conventionals see the biggest
increase, though in the case of the latter average monthly issuance until year end will
be lower than over the past eight months, as the DMO was well ahead of schedule.

PM11:11am

Market reaction suggests these increases were slightly larger than anticipated
In the aftermath of the Chancellor's speech, and the publication of the new Economic
and Fiscal Outlook by the OBR, and of the new Financing Arithmetic by the DMO, the
conventional Gilt curve has bear steepened and issues across the curve have cheapened
by about 3bp on asset swap. We see any underperformance as likely to be short lived,
as confirmation there will be no large infrastructure related pick up in borrowing,
ongoing QE, and forthcoming coupon payments all support to the market.

11:11 am
PM11:12am

We view these forecasts as optimistic, and likely to be pared back in due course
The GDP forecasts for the next two years remain comfortably above our own
expectations (1.0% in 2017, 0.7% in 2018) even after today's revisions. They are
closely aligned with the forecasts (of 1.4% and 1.5%) published by the Bank of
England (BoE) in the recent November Quarterly Inflation Report (QIR), which we view
as based on optimistic expectations about the outlook for the consumer driven by a
forecast of accelerating wage inflation. We think the labour market will soften next
year as companies act on the more negative investment intentions they have reported
since the EU referendum, and that wages will stagnate or slow.

PM11:12am

EU exit deadline likely to mean growth keeps slowing for longer than assumed
The two year deadline mandated by Article 50 for the UK's formal exit from the EU is
expected to fall at the end of the first quarter of 2019, and we believe any clarity about
transitional or more permanent trade and other arrangements after this deadline will be
thin on the ground until very late in the process. In our view, this will likely cause
uncertainty and defensive sentiment to intensify throughout this period, and highlights
why we forecast that GDP will not reaccelerate in 2018 – as expected by the OBR and
the BoE – but will continue to lose momentum. This is one reason why we think the
MPC will need to consider endorsing additional QE around the middle of next year.

PM11:12am

Watch it Wraith. You'll have the Mail after you

11:13 am
PM11:13am

And Credit Suisse

BE11:13am

(@Jimmy: GBPEUR also pinged. Not sure why. Asking.)

PM11:13am

Anais Boussie

11:13 am
PM11:13am

Quick Take: Autumn Statement shows much
slower growth and higher borrowing

PM11:14am

Phillip Hammond delivered the Autumn Statement confronted by a nearterm
economic slowdown and a deterioration in public finances.
 Growth was downgraded as expected due to Brexit uncertainty hitting
consumption and investment.
 The fiscal surplus target was abandoned by 2019/20 as expected and
borrowing figures were revised up throughout. Overall £122bn was added
to planned borrowing over the next five years, higher than the £100bn
expected, with the Brexit vote adding £59bn to the borrowing figure.
 While this represents a significant loosening of fiscal policy compared to
March, a large discretionary fiscal stimulus package which would add
significantly to growth in the near term wasn’t announced.
 However the Chancellor gave himself room and flexibility to add more
stimulus in case the economy needs it in light of the uncertainty of the
growth outlook.

PM11:14am

The government has proposed new fiscal targets, which are much less
constraining than the existing ones:
A) Aim for balanced budget in next Parliament but structural deficit –
below 2% of GDP in 2020-21.
B) Net debt must fall relative to GDP in 2020-21.
C) The new welfare cap only applies in 2021-22 and is only to be
assessed at the start of the next Parliament.
 Policy announcements were mainly on increased investment.
 It was announced that the Autumn Statement will be abolished and the next
spring budget would be the last one. From autumn 2017, there will an
autumn budget instead of a spring budget. There will be a spring statement
from 2018 that will respond to OBR’s forecasts, but it would not be a major
fiscal event with big changes. Hence the autumn budget will be the one big
fiscal event of the year instead of having two.
 Overall UK cash requirements rose by £20.6bn in 2016/17 in line with our
expectations but more than the market expected (markets were expecting a
4.3bn rise in gilts). A £15bn rise in gilts and 5.6bn in Tbills was announced.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

There, that'll do

undefined
PM11:14am

Shall we move to individual stocks?

11:14 am
BE11:15am

We can, though not starting with the usual for once.

BE11:15am

BE11:15am

To Switzerland, specifically.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Because .....

BE11:16am

http://www.streeti...urce/12281595.html

BE11:16am

Switzerland-based Actelion has attracted takeover interest, according to a person claiming to have knowledge of the matter. The source hinted that the mystery buyer is likely a major U.S.-based pharmaceutical company, but he wouldn't reveal the bidder’s name or the offer price. The ADR's of Actelion trade thinly in the U.S. under the ticker symbol (OTC: ALIOY).

11:16 am
BE11:16am

New Jersey-based Johnson & Johnson (NYSE: JNJ) and Paris-based Sanofi (NYSE: SNY) were previously mentioned as potential suitors for the Swiss drug company, but Actelion management has in the past been quick to downplay the idea that it’s a takeover target.

BE11:16am

,,,,,,,, So ................

BE11:16am

We, along with every other M&A hack in the Western world, have been chasing this story for about a month.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

There's a big wall of speculative money sitting behind Actelion right now ....

BE11:17am

.... so this RAW disclaimer is particularly important.

BE11:17am

But since Streetinsider is wearing some of the risk for us, here's the general gist of the rumour.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

We've been hearing that Actelion has had a firm approach reasonably recently, and that it brought in BOA Merrill Lynch to do the defence.

BE11:19am

We also hear that there's a firm deadline on that offer, as in this week. After that, the predator has threatened to go hostile.

PM11:20am

This is all v v interesting

11:20 am
BE11:20am

The price we've heard is .... actually, I'll not be specific here. But there's a price around.

PM11:21am

But it's yet to show through vividly in the stock price

PM11:21am

Actually just getting going now

11:21 am
BE11:21am

In terms of the potential buyers, J&J seems a credible one. Though J&J traditionally says it doesn't do hostile.

BE11:22am

There's also the theory that Actelion might just be looking at partnerships, so is talking to lots of companies, but has BOAML at its back in case anyone gets the wrong idea.

BE11:22am

And as StreetInsider says, Actelion has in the past played down the idea that it's for sale.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

..... So anyway. There's lots more on my notepad about this one, but there's no point in gifting stuff to the competition.

PM11:23am

The stock's trading 1.55% higher -- at 157.50

BE11:24am

Plus, my knowledge of the Swiss takeover code isn't what it could be. Let's just say that the rumour looks a decent one, but also that it's a pretty widely disseminated rumour already.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

For now, add it to your watch list. That's all.

PM11:24am

Sheesh, this thing has a market cap of 17bn swiss francs

PM11:24am

Hadn't realised

11:24 am

BE11:27am

PM11:28am

http://www.investe...1611240700089974P/

Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 171.00, down 22.9 (-11.81%), High: 181.50, Low: 165.90, Volume: 1.66m

11:30 am
PM11:30am

BE11:30am

Or rather, everyone thinks their house is worth less than it was in the summer and is too scared to crystalise that entirely theoretical loss.

BE11:31am

Bloody London. Idiotic market.

11:30 am

BE11:31am

reported revenues -4.4% y-o-y at £558.7m

BE11:31am

BE11:32am

BE11:32am

11:32 am
BE11:33am

That's the stamp duty change increasing supply.

BE11:33am

In terms of the warning, 2016 EBITDA to be around the lower end of market expectations

BE11:33am

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Transaction volumes down -6% in 2016. 2017 likely to be worse.

BE11:34am

But why am I typing all this when you could just read it from an analyst? Here's Citi.

BE11:34am

Countrywide today reported 3Q16 trading update highlighting continued challenging conditions within the UK residential property market post the EU referendum. The group now expects FY16e transaction volumes to decline -6% YoY (Citi +1% YoY) with FY16e EBITDA to be at lower end of market expectations (Citi £98.1m; Factset consensus mean of £90.8m; range £85.0m- £96.6m). The group also expects FY17e market transactions to be lower than FY16e (Citi -1% YoY).

11:34 am
BE11:34am

3Q16 Revenues were £188.5m (down -4% YoY; Citi 2H16e Revenues -9.6% YoY) with YTD Revenues of £558.7m (+4% YoY; Citi FY16e -0.8% YoY). Retail Transactions were down -1% in 3Q16 (Citi -1% in 2H16e) with YTD Retail Transactions +7% (Citi +5% for FY16e). London Transactions were down -29% in 3Q16 (Citi -30% in 2H16e) with YTD Retail Transactions down -11% (Citi -16% for FY16e). Post changes to stamp duty, the Letting market had seen an influx in the supply rental properties resulting in downward pressure on rental growth. YTD Retail lettings properties under management were up +15% (Citi +2% for FY16e) and London lettings properties under management were up +4% (Citi +5% for FY16e).

BE11:34am

Countywide shares, alongside other listed UK Estate Agents, have performed poorly in 2016, down c52% YTD. The shares are trading at a CY17E PE of 6.5x supported by an attractive 7.7% dividend yield (ordinary DPS). Despite weak price performance of late, we remain Neutral given a lack of near-term visibility on a recovery in UK sales transaction volumes.

BE11:34am

3Q16 Trading update highlighted continued challenging conditions within the UK residential property market post EU referendum with FY16e EBITDA expected at lower end of market expectations (Citi £98.1m; Factset consensus mean of £90.8m; range of £85.0m- £96.6m) implying mid-single digit consensus downgrades.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

And Jefferies. The excellent Anthony Coddling.

BE11:35am

If we sidestep the elephant, which yesterday moved into a rental property, Countrywide's trading update is in-line with our expectations. Our CY16E EBITDA of £85m is 15% below the Bloomberg consensus of £100m. Our estimate is the lowest in the range and the Group is guiding around the 'lower end of market expectations'. We are not changing our estimates today, but we suspect others will.

BE11:35am

Transaction volumes. Expected to be 6% down on 2015 (we estimate a 15% decline in London and 5% decline elsewhere) and the Group expects the level of market transactions in 2017 to be lower than the outturn for 2016 (we estimate 10% decline in London and a 5% decline elsewhere). In our view volumes have been tempered by uncertainty surrounding Brexit and the continued gulf between buyers and sellers pricing expectations following the Stamp Duty changes of December 2014 and April 2016.
Lettings: a gold rush with predictable an outcome. A rush of transactions in Q1 to beat the stamp duty change has led to the supply of rental properties growing at a faster rate than the number of tenants, with rental price growth slowing in some areas and falling in others.
Headwinds shrinking pipelines. Although revenue in the year to 30 Sep 16 at £558.7m is 4% ahead of the same period last year, pipelines at the end of September were down 16% and 26% for the Retail and London businesses, respectively, which largely explains why we expect EBITDA to fall 25% in FY16. We assume flat profits in FY17.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Foxtons not really doing much, I note, having dropped pretty heavily through yesterday.

PM11:07am

Sorry late

BE11:37am

Here's Jefferies again.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

At the time of writing no agent had publicly quantified or even provided guidance about its revenue and profit exposure to tenant fees. The following estimates therefore come with a health warning and show our view, not that of the agents themselves, of a worst case scenario with no mitigation. We estimate that the FY17 revenue and PBT exposure to tenant fees are as follows: Foxtons c.£4.5m of revenue and c.£3.2m of PBT; Countrywide £20m and £10m; LSL £11m and £5.5m; Purplebricks £0.4m and £0.2m. If we assume that changes to fee structures could mitigate half of the profit exposure, we estimate that the overall impact on FY 2017 PBT (on the assumption the ban was effective on 1 January 2017) would be: Foxtons: 6.7%; Countrywide 9.2%; LSL 9.2%; and Purplebricks 2.5%.

undefined
PM11:37am

Purple bricks needs a mention

11:37 am
PM11:37am

http://www.investe...1611240700090018Q/

BE11:38am

...................Oh yeah.

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 113.44, up 4.44 (+4.07%), High: 114.50, Low: 110.00, Volume: 36.68k
11:38 am
PM11:38am

Tenant fees charged by Purplebricks are modest and highly competitive, when benchmarked against peers. Up-front fees for tenants are currently £175 (inc VAT) outside London and £209 (inc VAT) in London. Purplebricks does not charge renewal fees. Purplebricks anticipates that it can adapt the model swiftly and at minimal cost and when combined with its low fixed overhead model and pricing structure, should prove even more attractive for landlords seeking excellent service and better value.

BE11:38am

Taking back what it lost yesterday, pretty much.

PM11:38am

They are just using it as a PR opportunity

11:38 am
PM11:39am

Quite sensible i guess

BE11:39am

Purplebricks still has a few questions to answer about its business model, and where the rewards are placed for its agents.

BE11:41am

As in, they get their commission at the "Sold STC" point rather than the "Sold" point, and anyone who's ever bought a house knows that getting between those points is a long walk through the valley of the shadow of death ......

11:41 am
BE11:41am

... whatever. Have some Liberum.

BE11:41am

Countrywide's profit warning does not alter our view on Rightmove (BUY, TP 5000p) and ZPG (BUY, TP 415p). The online property portal's business model insulates them from small delta's in housing transactions and we estimate it would take a significant decline of +10% in 2017 to trigger estate agents closures. We envisage a scenario similar to 2011/12 where 2017 transaction levels are down 5-10%. A transaction decline of this magnitude would be supportive of our current forecasts and we would highlight that even with transaction levels down 6% YTD, Rightmove managed to deliver a record ARPA growth for H1'16 and an underlying EPS growth of 19%.

BE11:42am

We also highlight that estate agents are much healthier and diversified businesses post 2008/09. For instance, the number of lettings offices that have opened according to The Property Ombudsman data has grown at a 12% CAGR since 2010 compared to Sales offices growth of 5%. Lettings revenues tend to be more robust during a slowdown and in fact tend to increase. This also combats the issue of seasonal cash flow that historically has affected Estate Agents. Estate Agents have also grown the proportion of ancillary revenues which gives them an additional source of revenues vs 2008/09. For example, Countrywide estimate that they now generate 50p in ancillary revenues for every £1 of Estate Agency revenue.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Etc.

Sound Energy PLC (SOU:LSE): Last: 80.55, down 0.95 (-1.17%), High: 84.00, Low: 79.75, Volume: 3.86m

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Someone was asking about gold

PM11:49am

I happen to have some ABN Amro to hand

PM11:49am

They don't like it

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Trump leaves its mark on precious metal prices

Gold prices rallied temporarily on Donald Trump’s election victory. However, investor sentiment made a dramatic U-turn. The sharp rise in US Treasury yields and the rally in US equity markets in an environment of positive investor sentiment triggered a substantial rally in the US dollar and caused a crash in gold prices. The price behaviour signals that every rally in gold prices is used as an opportunity by investors to unwind existing long gold positions. This is a negative sign for the gold price outlook. This week gold prices cleared the psychological level of USD 1,200 per ounce as the rally in US Treasury yields and the US dollar continued on better than expected US economic data releases. Since the US presidential elections gold prices have dropped 7%, platinum by 8% and silver by 11%. Meanwhile, palladium prices rose in tandem with industrial metal prices driven by expectations of higher demand and positive investor sentiment.

PM11:50am

We remain negative on gold for 2017

We expect the current negative environment to remain in place for gold prices in 2017. Investor demand remains the most crucial driver pushing gold prices lower. From an investor point of view there is little reason to hold gold as an investment. For a start, rising inflation expectations are more than countered by the rise in US Treasury yields and expectations about upcoming rate hikes by the Fed. As a result, US real yields are rising which is a major negative for gold prices. Moreover, higher inflation expectations have not triggered major inflation fear (yet). As long as real yields rise and there are no major inflation fears, gold prices will go lower and not higher. What is more, the last leg of a powerful rally in the US dollar is in full swing. This is a powerful cyclical rally where higher US equities, expectations of more Fed rate hikes and expectations of a strong uplift in the US economy drive the US dollar. This is being reflected in the portfolio inflows into US equities and cyclical bonds. Investors will find zero-income paying asset gold and other precious metals unattractive because of higher income in equities and bonds, with the exception of palladium, which has a strong cyclical exposure.

PM11:50am

The net long positions in the futures market and in ETFs have been reduced but overall positions are still large. In the current environment we expect investor position liquidation to continue leading to a cutback in net-positions in the futures market to an average level of 100,000 contracts and also a considerable cutback in total ETF positions. Therefore, we expect that gold prices will drop towards USD 1,100 (above the low set in 2015). Lower gold prices will likely stimulate jewellery demand and industrial demand. We expect jewellery demand and industrial demand to rise at a modest pace. This will not compensate for lower investor demand but merely dampen the size of the move down.

11:50 am
PM11:50am

But...

PM11:50am

…but a recovery in gold prices in 2018

If gold prices are able to bottom out above the 2015 low (USD 1,046 per ounce), investors will likely be more willing to buy gold as the price is more attractive. In 2018, we expect the US growth/inflation mix to deteriorate meaning that US growth will slow down while inflation remains relatively high. Therefore, the Fed will continue to hike interest rates in 2015. This should be negative for gold prices but by that time, our scenario for Fed rate hikes will likely be fully anticipated. We expect the US dollar to peak in 2017 and to weaken considerably in 2018. This is good news for gold prices as well as 10y US real rates will likely also peak and move lower. All together this should give an incentive for investors to position in gold again. This together with higher jewellery demand from China should support a price recovery back to USD 1,300 per ounce.

PM11:50am

Done

11:50 am
undefined
BE11:51am

@Watt is right to pick me up earlier on Purplebricks commission model. I should've been clearer.

BE11:51am

Its agents get a set fee per instruction of about £250

11:52 am
BE11:52am

But then there's a load of boosters for upselling additional services, such as conveyancing

BE11:52am

Those commissions seem to stop at the "Sold STC" point, which might encourage them to hit that point as quickly as possible even when the buyer seems unlikely to actually complete.

BE11:53am

That's a theory. It's a theory management's been asked about.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Anyway, just wanted to retrace that. What next?

BE11:53am

Direct Line leading us up .......

Direct Line Insurance Group PLC (DLG:LSE): Last: 361.70, up 13.3 (+3.82%), High: 362.50, Low: 356.50, Volume: 1.60m
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Morgan Stanley, house broker, turns positive.

BE11:54am

Direct Line's shift towards more own-brands business away from partnership business should lead to higher ROE, greater customer retention and higher quality of earnings. We upgrade to Overweight and raise our price target to 465p, offering c.30% upside.
Direct Line's investment in growing its own-brand policies should lead to higher ROE and greater customer retention. As commission costs decline and retention improves, the acquisition costs over the customer lifetime are lower, driving margins higher. We see ROE increasing from 16% in 2016 to 17.2% by 2019.

BE11:54am

Ongoing development and integration of IT infrastructure a key differentiating factor. Direct Line is updating and linking every separate IT system to optimise its product offering and reduce expenses. It is one of the few European insurers investing in this.
We think the market is missing the improving quality of earnings and resulting future dividend growth. Year to date, Direct Line has significantly underperformed listed peers, but we believe there is scope for dividend growth to follow the improvement in earnings, with continued special dividends and a gradual rise in the payout ratio over our forecast period. We also see earnings from prior year development declining relative to current year earnings, making reserve release sustainability less of a debate.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Our price target moves to 465p from 414p since we last published as we roll our price target forward to 2017 and take into account the expected margin improvements in the business. Our 2017 EPS moves to 32.38p from 30.21p on higher-than-expected motor premium rate development and forecasted margin expansion as retention improves and the commission ratio declines. We value Direct Line at 14.4x P/E FY17e with an EPS CAGR of 4.8% FY17-FY20e. Direct Line is currently trading at 12.0x 2017 consensus earnings.
Longer term, disruption in the UK motor market is a challenge for Direct Line, particularly given the long-term possible shrinkage of the motor market due to enhanced safety features on vehicles.

undefined
BE11:55am

BE12:02pm

Ahead of today's capital markets day, DOM has announced that it is increasing its long term target for the UK to 1,600 stores from 1,200 previously. At the current run rate, this equates to more than 8 years of estate growth at 6% CAGR. The group continues to trade well and management is reiterating FY guidance.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Increasing UK store count opportunity by 33%. With the continued strong store performance and successful strategy of splitting territories, management is increasing its long term target for the UK to reach 1,600 stores (timing undefined) from its previous target of 1,200. With 80 store openings planned this year, taking its store count to c.950, this run rate suggests more than 8 years of estate rollout at a CAGR of more than 6%.
At this point, there would be one store for every 33k people, which compares to DPE which is targeting one store for every 21k people in Australia by 2025.
● Upside risk to DCF valuation: We currently assume 6% p.a. revenue growth in the medium term in our DCF, comprised of 3% LFL growth and 3% estate growth. Each 1ppt increase in our revenue growth assumption adds 18p to our DCF valuation.
● International to be a meaningful contributor: With c.100 stores across Ireland, Switzerland and the Nordics by the end of 2016, management has identified opportunities to reach 400 stores. We currently forecast minimal store growth in Ireland or Switzerland by 2020 (+14 and +19 stores resp.) suggesting material upside to our store targets, in particular from the Nordics where there are fewer than 35 stores.
● FY16 guidance unchanged: The group is trading well and PBT guidance remains unchanged (NSe £83.3m). A rephasing of supply chain centre projects means capex in FY16 will be c.£13m lower than previously forecast. Demonstrating capital discipline, surplus cash will be returned to shareholders through buybacks albeit the current programme has been paused as it resolves an issue.
